titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ruth Gruber Papers TAM.745
titlestmt.author: Shiva Addanki, Kate Fisher, and Samantha Rowe

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-11-30 15:14:05 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 169 record cartons, 7 oversize boxes, 4 flat boxes, 5 manuscript boxes,1 half manuscript box, and 1 media box.

did.abstract: The Ruth Gruber Papers consists of photographs, slides, correspondence, and writings from 1922 to 2016, related to the personal and professional life of Dr. Ruth Gruber. Her educational experience as an undergraduate student at New York University during the 1920s and PhD studies at the Institute for International Education in Cologne, Germany during the 1930s is represented through writings, notebooks, correspondence, and travel documents. Gruber's work as a photojournalist and writer from 1932 to 2011 is reflected through her articles, notebooks, manuscripts, and correspondence generated while working for the New York Herald Tribune, the New York Post, and other publications. Additionally, this collection contains photographs, slides, audio and video recordings, electronic records, and digital images related to her journalistic work. Correspondence, travel documents, notebooks, films, slides, and photographs from 1941 to 1945 document Gruber's study of the former Alaska Territory while employed as a Department of Interior Field Representative. Her participation in a secret mission to Europe to escort one thousand Jewish refugees to Fort Ontario in Oswego, New York in 1944 is chronicled through her notebooks, photographs, clippings, and interviews. Gruber's personal life is reflected through her correspondence, photographs, slides, notebooks, and travel ephemera.
did.physloc: Some of these materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English, Hebrew, and German.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from David Michaels and Celia Michaels in February 2018; the accession number associated with this gift is 2018.127.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Ruth Gruber (1911-2016) was a photojournalist, author, and humanitarian from Brooklyn, NY. Born to a family of Russian Jewish immigrants, she enrolled at New York University at the age of fifteen, graduating in 1929. She completed a postgraduate fellowship at the University of Wisconsin and earned her PhD from the Institute for International Education in Cologne, Germany in 1932, becoming one of the youngest women in the world to receive a doctorate. Gruber was a foreign correspondent for the New York Herald Tribune, until she was hired by The U.S. Department of the Interior to study aspects of the former Alaska Territory in 1941. Upon her return to Washington, D.C., Gruber was appointed as Special Assistant to the Secretary of the Interior, Harold Ickes. In 1944 she worked on a classified wartime mission to escort one thousand Jewish Refugees from Naples, Italy into the U.S. at Fort Ontario, helping oversee and advocate for their permanent settlement in Oswego, NY. In 1946, Gruber returned to journalism, writing for the New York Post and continuing as a foreign correspondent for the New York Herald Tribune. In July 1947, at the Port of Haifa, Gruber covered the events involving British warships intercepting a steamship called Exodus 1947 which transported 4,515 refugees and survivors of the Holocaust. In 1951, Gruber began writing a column called "Diary of an American Housewife" in the magazine published by Hadassah, a Zionist women's organization.Gruber wrote nineteen books based on her experiences as a journalist, as well as her advocacy for Jewish refugees and the state of Israel after World War II. Throughout her seventy years as a journalist and humanitarian, she received five honorary doctorates and many other honors and recognitions, including the Na'amat Golda Meir Human Rights Award, awards from the Simon Wiesenthal Center's Museum of Tolerance, and others specifically for her books. Gruber died on November 17, 2016, at the age of 105.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Ruth Gruber Papers; TAM 745; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Before transfer to NYU Library, materials were packed and an inventory was created by those administering Gruber's estate. While still at Gruber's home, a portion of the material was repacked by NYU staff into more appropriately-sized containers, which changed the content description of the original inventory. Changes were notated when possible.

In 2018, at the time of accessioning, three graduate student workers rehoused material into archival boxes and folders when necessary. The boxes were renumbered and a new box level inventory was created. A column was included in the spreadsheet, notating original inventory box numbers/letters when possible. The material was described to the box-level. Born-digital items were separated from the material, boxed, labeled, and inventoried in Medialog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ruth Gruber Papers consists of photographs, slides, correspondence, and writings from 1922 to 2016, related to the personal and professional life of Dr. Ruth Gruber. Her educational experience as an undergraduate student at New York University during the 1920s and PhD studies at the Institute for International Education in Cologne, Germany during the 1930s is represented through writings, notebooks, correspondence, and travel documents. Gruber's work as a photojournalist and writer from 1932 to 2011 are reflected in articles, notebooks, manuscripts, and correspondence generated while working for the New York Herald Tribune, the New York Post, and other publications. Additionally, this collection contains photographs, slides, audio and video recordings, electronic records, and digital images related to her journalistic work. Correspondence, travel documents, notebooks, films, slides, and photographs from 1941 to 1945 document Gruber's study of the former Alaska Territory while employed as a Department of Interior Field Representative. Her participation in a secret mission to Europe to escort one thousand Jewish refugees to Fort Ontario in Oswego, New York in 1944 is chronicled through her notebooks, photographs, clippings, and interviews. Gruber's personal life is reflected through her correspondence, photographs, slides, notebooks, and travel ephemera.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
